captions.text:
Does the Universe Have a Purpose? I'm not
sure.

Anyone who expresses a more definitive response
to the question is claiming access to knowledge

not based on empirical foundations. This remarkably
persistent way of thinking, common to most

religions and some branches of philosophy,
has failed badly in past efforts to understand,

and thereby predict the operations of the
universe and our place within it.

To assert that the universe has a purpose
implies a desired outcome. But who would do

the desiring? And what would a desired outcome
be? That carbon-based life is inevitable?

Or that sentient primates are life's neurological
pinnacle? Of course humans were not around

to ask these questions for 99.9999% of cosmic
history. So if the purpose of the universe

was to create humans then the cosmos was embarrassingly
inefficient about it.

And if a further purpose of the universe was
to create a fertile cradle for life, then

our cosmic environment has got an odd way
of showing it. Life on Earth, during more

than 3.5 billion years of existence, has been
persistently assaulted by natural sources

of mayhem, death, and destruction. Ecological
devastation exacted by volcanoes, climate

change, earthquakes, tsunamis, storms, and
especially killer asteroids have left extinct

99.9% of all species that have ever lived
here.

How about human life itself? If you are religious,
you might declare that the purpose of life

is to serve God. But if you’re one of the
100 billion bacteria living and working in

a single centimeter of your lower intestine,
you might instead say that the purpose of

human life is to provide you with a dark,
but idyllic, anaerobic habitat of fecal matter.

So in the absence of human hubris, the universe
looks more and more random. Whenever events

that are purported to occur in our best interest
are as numerous as other events that would

just as soon kill us, then intent is hard,
if not impossible, to assert. So while I cannot

claim to know for sure whether or not the
universe has a purpose, the case against it

is strong, and visible to anyone who sees
the universe as it is rather than as they
wish it to be.
I'm Neil deGrasse Tyson.

I was asked by The Templeton Foundation to
respond to a question: Does the Universe Have
a Purpose?

title: Does the Universe Have a Purpose? feat. Neil deGrasse Tyson

comments.text:
It's true that the appropriate reaction to "What is the purpose of the 
universe?" is "To whom?" and it's very apt to point out that the implied 
answer to the last question, for anyone who did not ask it, is "to someone 
or something 'higher' than human beings". It's also important to recognize 
that there is nothing 'higher than us' in a meaningful sense that could 
actually give the universe a 'higher' purpose, than the purpose which we 
give to it ourselves. The belief in a purpose higher than ourselves is a 
major part of the destructiveness of religion and that concept must be 
dispensed with.

However, it is WRONG to assert that, lacking a "higher" purpose, the 
universe has no purpose at all. It has a purpose, which is the purpose it 
has for us. That purpose can still be objectively defined within certain 
parameters, in such a way as to guide one's life. Nihilism does not follow 
from atheism. This is an extremely important point which it's too bad Tyson 
missed.﻿

That's readily figured out by looking at wikipedia, macroevolution is 
evolution on a scale of separated gene pools.  The main issue that tends to 
come up in the creation/evolution thing is that Creationists tend to enact 
strategic elasticity as to how the phrase is defined depending on the 
examples presented them.

"2. what was the first eye found in the fossil record?"

Case in point here, in order for me to meaningfully answer this you'll have 
to provide a solid, concise definition of what specifically will constitute 
an "eye" within this debate, is simply photosensitive cells viable as an 
"eye", or are you talking about one specific iteration of the concept, a 
specific organ as differentiated from the other organs in the body?  In 
other words, at which point in the development of those simple 
photosensitive cells into the modern eye would you be looking for examples 
of?  This is a perfect example of the aforementioned strategic elasticity 
of terms I mentioned, if I answer without you providing an exact point of 
reference from which to form my answer you could simply discount that 
answer as "not eye-like enough" and discount the examples.

"3. give us the plans for dragonfly metamorphosis to occur."

This again is a vague question, are you asking what specific shifts were 
necessary for the species of dragonfly to develop from it's precursor 
species?  Or rather which traits are used to differentiate a modern day 
dragonfly from the ancestors from which it came?  You ask for "plans" but 
don't offer any framework from which to work in which I can do so in any 
concise, objective manner...is physical traits what you want?  genetic code 
distinctions?  It's like me saying "give me the plans for water to 
occur"...I could give the environment necessary for water to develop, 
simply give objective physical qualities of water (it's a wet blue liquid 
consisting of only two molecules necessary for life as we know it for 
example), give you just a straight up chemical breakdown (it's two parts 
hydrogen and one part oxygen), give you the standards necessary for water 
to "metamorph" into a solid state or a gaseous state and so forth and all 
would be correct.  The questions you're asking are too vague for anyone to
